1: <sup>1</sup> After this opened Job his mouth, and cursed his day.
3: <sup>3</sup> Let the day perish wherein I was born, and the night in which it was said, There is a man child conceived.
4: <sup>4</sup> Let that day be darkness; let not God regard it from above, neither let the light shine upon it.
5: <sup>5</sup> Let darkness and the shadow of death stain it; let a cloud dwell upon it; let the blackness of the day terrify it.
6: <sup>6</sup> As for that night, let darkness seize upon it; let it not be joined unto the days of the year, let it not come into the number of the months.
7: <sup>7</sup> Lo, let that night be solitary, let no joyful voice come therein.
8: <sup>8</sup> Let them curse it that curse the day, who are ready to raise up their mourning.
9: <sup>9</sup> Let the stars of the twilight thereof be dark; let it look for light, but have none; neither let it see the dawning of the day:
10: <sup>10</sup> Because it shut not up the doors of my mother’s womb, nor hid sorrow from mine eyes.
11: <sup>11</sup> Why died I not from the womb? why did I not give up the ghost when I came out of the belly?
12: <sup>12</sup> Why did the knees prevent me? or why the breasts that I should suck?
13: <sup>13</sup> For now should I have lain still and been quiet, I should have slept: then had I been at rest,
14: <sup>14</sup> With kings and counsellors of the earth, which build desolate places for themselves;
15: <sup>15</sup> Or with princes that had gold, who filled their houses with silver:
16: <sup>16</sup> Or as an hidden untimely birth I had not been; as infants which never saw light.
17: <sup>17</sup> There the wicked cease from troubling; and there the weary be at rest.
18: <sup>18</sup> There the prisoners rest together; they hear not the voice of the oppressor.
19: <sup>19</sup> The small and great are there; and the servant is free from his master.
20: <sup>20</sup> Wherefore is light given to him that is in misery, and life unto the bitter in soul;
21: <sup>21</sup> Which long for death, but it cometh not; and dig for it more than for hid treasures;
22: <sup>22</sup> Which rejoice exceedingly, and are glad, when they can find the grave?
23: <sup>23</sup> Why is light given to a man whose way is hid, and whom God hath hedged in?
24: <sup>24</sup> For my sighing cometh before I eat, and my roarings are poured out like the waters.
25: <sup>25</sup> For the thing which I greatly feared is come upon me, and that which I was afraid of is come unto me.
26: <sup>26</sup> I was not in safety, neither had I rest, neither was I quiet; yet trouble came.
